(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

<|im_start|>user
Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Using inclusion-exclusion: P(at least one homozgyo) = 5*(1/4) - 10*(1/16) + 10*(1/64) - ... but this quickly becomes complex. Alternatively, maybe it's easier to calculate the complement: probability of not being homozygous for any gene pair. For one gene pair, the probability of not being homozygous is 3/4. For five independent gene pairs, it's (3/4)^5 ≈ 0.2373. So the probability of being homozygous at least once is 1 - 0.2373 ≈ 0.7627, which is roughly 7627/10000, but scaled to 1024, it's approximately 778/1024 ≈ 0.76. But the closest option is E, which is 1/32 (~0.03125) for part (a), 1/1024 (~0.0009766) for part (b), and 255/1024 (~0.2490234). These don't align with my calculations. Alternatively, perhaps the options are simplified fractions, and 255/1024 is the exact value for someone who considers all possible non-dominant genotypes, but that still doesn't resolve why it's 255/1024.

Given the confusion, perhaps I should accept that the correct answers are A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1024, but wait, the options given don't have 1023/1024. The correct answer is E

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>
